awd_abstract_narration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. One of the most exciting quests in particle physics is the search for new particles beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. Extensions of the standard model predict not only new particles with masses above the electroweak scale (about 100 billion electron-volts, eV), but also so-called WISPs (Weakly Interacting Sub-eV Particles). The most famous WISP candidate is the axion, which has been introduced to explain the smallness of Charge-Parity (CP) violation in Quantum ChromoDynamics and which turns out to also be a prime candidate for a constituent of the dark matter in the universe. Similarly, axion-like particles, light spin 1 particles called "hidden sector photons," seem to occur naturally in realistic embeddings of the standard model into string theory. It is therefore an important and fundamental question whether any of these weakly-interacting light particles exists. The Any Light Particle Search (ALPS) experiment will give students and postdoctoral scientists the opportunity to develop scientific skills from a diverse set of disciplines spanning lasers and optics, electronics and feedback control systems, vacuum and cryogenics, computational methods and data analysis algorithm development, large-scale detector commissioning and operation, dark-matter physics and cosmology. The required technologies are spin-offs of technologies which were developed for ground and space-based gravitational-wave detectors. The work supported by this award would build on these investments and would allow continued development of high performance optical techniques and devices which have commercial applications in the laser and optics industries.

The ALPS experiment under development at DESY in Germany is a 'light-shining-through-walls' search, where photons are projected to be converted into weakly interacting light particles which pass unimpeded through an opaque wall and convert (in part) back to photons behind the wall. The most famous of these particles are axions which require a strong magnetic field to convert to photons. Other particles which fall within the ALPS portfolio include hidden-sector photons which couple linearly to the electromagnetic field and do not require a static magnetic field. The planned ALPS@DESY experiments are the leading background-independent searches for axions and hidden sector photons. The improved sensitivity of ALPS would enable, for the first time, a purely laboratory experiment to probe axion-photon couplings at a level competitive with, or superior to, limits from stellar evolution or solar searches. The experiment only depends on the fundamental photon-axion interaction and not on solar models nor on assumptions about dark matter.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Any Light Particle Search II (ALPS II) is a light shining through a wall (LSW) experiment. ALPS II is an international scientific collaboration led by the ALPS DESY group in Hamburg, Germany, where the experiment is also located. UF is the second largest and only US partner in this essential dark matter search. 

At a fundamental level, ALPS searches for non-standard model interactions involving a photon and a non-standard model particle inside a static magnetic field. The best known predicted non-standard model particle is the axion and our experiment searches for light-weight axions and axion-like particles with masses less than a millionth of the mass of the electron. Such an interaction would turn a minuscule fraction of photons inside a first magnetic field into axions which then pass through an opaque wall into a second magnetic field which turns a few of them back into photons thus shining light through a wall. 

LSW experiments are unique compared to other axion search experiments which depend on external assumptions about naturally occurring axion fluxes passing through their experiments. LSW experiments probe the interaction directly without any additional assumptions.

 

ALPS II is in many ways a close to ultimate LSW experiment. We use two 120m long strings of super-conducting, straightened 5.3T HERA dipole magnets on each side of the wall. This length limits the upper axion mass range we can probe to values ranging from 0 to 100?eV. ALPS II also uses high finesse optical cavities to (a) store as many photons inside the first string as possible and to (b) amplify the regenerated field inside the second string as much as possible. The result of all these measures is an increase in the regenerated photon rate by 12 orders of magnitude compared to earlier LSW experiments.

 

Figure 1 shows a picture of the ALPS II experiment prior to the installation of the central clean room. In the center is the vacuum chamber that holds the central optical bench which includes the wall. The axion production string extends 120m to the right where the high power laser beam is injected. The photon regeneration string extends 120m to the left where the heterodyne detection system is installed.

 

Over the last year, the ALPS II collaboration made significant progress. The magnet strings are now operational, all three clean rooms have been installed and certified, and the optics installation and commissioning work is near completion. During the last years, the UF group built and aligned the central optical bench ? the heart of the experiment ? and set up the injection system for the local oscillator (LO) laser. The LO is used to control the regeneration cavity and acts as a local oscillator for the signal field in the heterodyne sensing scheme we developed at UF. The UF group also set up the digital signal processing system used for the alignment sensing and control system, built and helped to commission the length sensing and control servos and the phase lock loops between the various laser sources. This work continues to be essential to start the first science runs in 2023 first with limited sensitivity and later with the final sensitivity probing parameter ranges which challenge interpretations of several astronomical observations. We also started to investigate scatter light issues and electromagnetic interferences, the most important of all expected systematic challenges of ALPS II. The design of the central optical bench was driven by the plan to minimise the chances of photons to make it around the wall (scattered light) while producing the necessary signals to control and equalise the lengths of both cavities with pm accuracy. For this purpose, the power on the COB was carefully managed to ensure adequate protection from scattered light while having enough signal for all control signals.

To give an idea about the challenge, we currently inject about 10^20 photons per second on one side of the experiment and with the wall open detect about 300ph/s on the other side of the regeneration cavity.

Modified by: Guido Mueller
